repository owners to set up their own standalone config.

While this enhance the ease of use, it does not offer our users the
flexibility to overrule the standalone configuration with their own.

Let's add an additional configuration column in repo-config.csv to
forcibly use the user supplied configuration by ignoring the one
defined by the repository owner.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#271] Support specifying of file formats at repo level (#295)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense allows specifying of file formats for analysis through CLI.

However, this sets all repositories to the same file formats.

Let's make file formats configurable in CSV and standalone configs
to improve usage on repositories with different file formats
and codebases.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#317] Add repo as alias to repos in CLI  (#322)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense accepts repository locations with argument -repos.

The plurality is not intuitive for first-time users, who wish
to use one repository.

Let's add repo as an alias to repos to make the CLI more inituive.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#366] Fix NullPointerException when accessing unfilled displayName in StandaloneConfig (#368)
commitResults.messageBody:
In our user guide, we allow most of the fields under the authors'
configuration to be optional other than the GitHub Id. Particularly
`Display Name`, which is suppose to use GitHub Id value when it is not
provided. However, when the display name is not filled in the
standalone config, the program crashes due to a NullPointerException.

This is because standalone config adopts the json format. When a field
is not filled in, in the json file, it will be initialized as null when
deserialized into a java object. This was unforeseen and was left
unchecked when accessing the variable.

Let's fix this by returning an empty string as the default value of
display name in the event of a null case, and also include unit tests
for StandaloneConfig parser.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#413] Update Travis-CI configuration to fix pcre2 dependency (#414)
commitResults.messageBody:
Git in Travis macosx image lacked pcre2 dependency to run checkstyle.
Thus, a line was added to reinstall Git with pcre2.

However, Git is then updated to use pcre2 by default and --with-pcre2
option was removed. This missing option causes Travis to fail.

Let's remove the line to reinstall Git with pcre2 in Travis configuration
to fix the issue.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#402] Make StandaloneConfig foolproof to exceptions caused by trailing commas (#412)
commitResults.messageBody:
Extra trailing commas is non-compliant to JSON standards.

This causes gson to improperly parse a list, creating additional
null elements, resulting NullPointerException in RepoConfiguration#update.

Let's prevent NullPointerException by removing null elements in lists.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#23, #470] Use Travis-CI to automate publishing of report to GitHub Pages (#497)
commitResults.messageBody:
Travis-CI offers cron jobs, which is used to trigger builds at certain
intervals.

Together with GitHub Pages, they can be utilized to make RepoSense a
cloud application, where it can periodically run analysis and update the
report to a live site.

Let's utilize Travis-CI to automate publishing of RepoSense report to
GitHub Pages, removing manual intervention for report updating.

commitResults.messageTitle: Remove redundant commands in Travis config (#551)
commitResults.messageBody:
In the Travis config file, we specify our Linux environment to use
JDK9 with `jdk: oraclejdk9` and `addons.apt.packages key`, but the
latter is redundant. Similarly, the command used to install frontend
npm dependencies can be simpified. The cd command does not change the
install location of the npm dependencies as frontend folder does not
contain a package.json file.

Let's remove the redundant commands for clarity and maintainability.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#537] build.gradle: fix files compilation order (#552)
commitResults.messageBody:
Nits to message:

```
We use `./gradlew run` in development to conveniently run RepoSense
without the need to build a Jar.

It is expected to do the following tasks sequentially:

[a] npmRunSpuild - build frontend/src to frontend/build
[b] zipReport    - zip `frontend/build` to resource of zip
[c] build   	 - build src to build files
[d] run          - execute the build files

However, when we execute the command, `./gradlew run --dry-run`
to list the running order, it differs from the expectation.

Actual order:
:compileJava		[c]
:processResources 	[c]
:classes 	        [c]
:downloadNode 		[a]
:npmInstall 		[a]
:npmRunSpuild 		[a]
:zipReport 	        [b]
:run 			[d]

Expected order:
:downloadNode		[a]
:npmInstall		[a]
:npmRunSpuild		[a]
:zipReport		[b]
:compileJava		[c]
:processResources	[c]
:classes		[c]
:run 			[d]

The incorrect order may result in RepoSense failing due to missing
templateZip or using an outdated templateZip.

Let's fix the issue by correctly chaining the task dependencies.
```

commitResults.messageTitle: [#537] build.gradle: change tasks dependencies to compileJava (#563)
[#557] Travis: check scripts do not work in Travis macOS environment (#559)
commitResults.messageBody:
Following #414, the line to reinstall `git` with `pcre2` was removed in
Travis macOS environment. As running `brew reinstall --with-pcre2 git`
would caused Travis to fail. Furthermore, `pcre2` now ships with
`git >= 2.19`.

Since its removal, check scripts, that depends on `pcre2`, do not work
but Travis macOS still passes. This is due to the use of an older
version of git which does not comes with `pcre2`.

Let's use the latest version of Travis macOS image, that comes with git
2.19.1, to ensure check scripts run correctly.

commitResults.messageTitle: Downgrade to JDK8 in CIs (#556)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense is advertised to run on JDK 1.8.0_60 and later.

However, we use JDK 9 in our CIs.

Let's downgrade to use JDK 8 in CIs to validate this non-functional
requirement.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#480] Use Cypress to automate front-end testing (#555)
commitResults.messageBody:
UI has been relying on reviewers to test it manually. While it promotes
shorter development time, our product's reliability has suffered in the
recent UI development. 

Let's integrate Cypress into our CI to automate the front-end testing
in CI to ensure better reliability.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#391] GitLsTree: validate filepaths before cloning (#564)
commitResults.messageBody:
Unix and Windows use a different set of invalid characters, with the
latter being more restrictive.

A valid file path in Unix may be invalid in Windows, which causes git
clone to fail. We classify this error generally as GitCloneException,
which may not be useful in conveying the exact cause of error.

Let's validate file paths and use a more specialized exception to log
invalid file paths, when analysis is done on Windows.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#648]: .travis.yml: change oraclejdk8 to openjdk8 (#650)
commitResults.messageBody:
The oracle-java8-installer in our .travis.yml refers to
ppa:webupd8team/java repository. According to the repo maintainer[1],
the repository has been discontinued due to "licensing issues".
Similarly, the homebrew java8[2] has been removed as well.

Let's update .travis.yml to use openjdk8 instead.

[1]: https://launchpad.net/~webupd8team/+archive/ubuntu/java
[2]: https://www.chuchur.com/article/mac-install-and-uninstall-java-jdk

commitResults.messageTitle: [#606] Enable use of deploy key for publishing (#732)
commitResults.messageBody:
In the publishing guide, instructions were given to generate personal
access token to grant write-access to RepoSense for publishing.

Despite ease of setup, personal access token may not be as secure as it
can access all other repositories owned by the user.

Let's also support deploy key for enhanced security, which enables user
to grant access to only a single repository.

commitResults.messageTitle: DeveloperGuide: add setup instructions
Setup travis to execute test code
Travis: add files standardization tests
Fix file standardization violations
Checkstyle: fix some violations 1
Checkstyle: fix some violations 2
Checkstyle: fix some violations 3
Checkstyle: fix some violations 4
Checkstyle: fix some violations 5
Checkstyle: fix some violations 6
Checkstyle: fix some violations 7
Travis: add checkstyle to CI test
[#64] README: embed travis status badge (#67)
[#73] Move test repository inside reposense organisation (#74)
[#70] Remove GUI (#77)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense is primarily a CLI app.

Let us remove the GUI to make the development effort more focused for the time
being.

commitResults.messageTitle: Docs: add work process guidelines (#75)
commitResults.messageBody:
Process guidelines help to define each respective member's role in the
project. It also helps to streamline repeatable tasks which minimizes
room for errors and increases overall efficiency.

Let's add the process guide to help us better in facilitating
operations in an organization.

commitResults.messageTitle: Gradle: replace build with shadowJar plugin (#68)
commitResults.messageBody:
Gradle build compiles our source files and libraries used in the
program into separate jar files, and delivers the entire package as
a zip file.

It is rather inconvenient as user would have to extract from the zip
file to use it and also have more unnecessary files to deal with.
Additionally, if we package only our own class files into the JAR
file, it will not work properly unless the user has all the other 
JAR files (i.e. third party libraries) our classes depend on.

Let's replace the gradle build with shadowJar plugin to package all
dependencies into a single JAR file which enhance usability and
portability.

commitResults.messageTitle: Prefix all packages with organisation name (#80)
commitResults.messageBody:
Prefixing our packages with organization name prevents name clashes.
It also ensures that our packages will be grouped together, following
our import order coding standard.

commitResults.messageTitle: Docs: add using Checkstyle-IDEA plugin on IntelliJ (#76)
Gradle: upgrade to version 4.7 (#83)
commitResults.messageBody:
Gradle does not recognise Java 9 version.

This is likely due to gradle version being out-dated for too long.

Let's update gradle to latest version so that it is compatible with
the newer version of Java.

commitResults.messageTitle: Fix main class could not be found (#89)
commitResults.messageBody:
The jar file built by gradle shadowjar plugin throws a could not
find or load main class error.

This is due to the recent renaming of packages in the project (#80)
and the mainClassName in gradle wasn't updated correspondingly.

Let's apply this fix in the build.gradle.

commitResults.messageTitle: Travis: add functional to CI test (#96)
commitResults.messageBody:
Functional test is a skeleton of an end-to-end testing infrastructure.

Let's add functional to the continuous integration test to ensure that
our system is consistent and viable to the users.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#72] Remove threading (#104)
commitResults.messageBody:
Threading starves our development PC of processing power, and also
causes the issue of randomized output.

Let's remove threading temporarily for now.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#69] Remove RepoInfo's dependency on FileInfo (#95)
commitResults.messageBody:
Separate the association between Commits and Authorship analysis is
necessary for us to match the proposed architecture in #69. 

Let's start by removing FileInfo from RepoInfo model.

commitResults.messageTitle: TestUtil: add file content comparison method (#122)
commitResults.messageBody:
Unlike diff tools, Assert.assertEquals does not provide useful 
information when the content in 2 File objects are not the same. 

This makes troubleshooting difficult. As without a clear indication, 
it is hard to trace the errors.

Let's implement the functionality of printing line differences by 
adding the method TestUtil#compareFileContents.

commitResults.messageTitle: Split contribution summary by repository #69 (#111)
commitResults.messageBody:
Contribution summary of each person in each and every repositories 
are consolidated into a single file.

This leads to heavy memory usage, and creates slow-to-respond
interfaces.

Let's split the contribution summary by repository to reduce the
system load, and as a step towards progressive web page loading.

commitResults.messageTitle: Fix datetime inconsistency (#125)
commitResults.messageBody:
Several date time inconsistency exists in the project.
1. Instead of designated constants, raw values are being used in month
   field of Calender setter.
2. Time zone and hours were not specified in the git log command
   execution.

This leads to disagreeing outputs when running the program at
different timing or on different machine.

Let's fix the date time inconsistency by
1. using the designated constants,
2. and fixed formatted values.

commitResults.messageTitle: Setup AppVeyor CI (#142)
commitResults.messageBody:
AppVeyor is a continuous integration service, similar to Travis but
uses Windows virtual machines. Also, employing a secondary service
allows it to be executed in parallel with current CI service.

Let's integrate AppVeyor support in our pull request checks to prevent
our application fails on Windows machines.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#140] Cleanup user guide (#146)
Dashboard revamp (#163)
commitResults.messageBody:
There are 2 main templates loaded separately to process the information
from the generated report. This requires the same template files to be
regenerated multiple times, which greatly increases the size of the
generated report unnecessarily. Ideally, it should only contains the
data for the report.

Also, as the dashboard uses vue for its templating engine mostly, let's
better utilize the framework to restructure the dashboard into a single
page application which loads content from the report dynamically.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#226] Add clickable link to repositories (#281)
commitResults.messageBody:
To view the repository, user needs to manually open the link to navigate to it.

Let's simplify this by adding a redirect link to the remote repositories in the
dashboard itself.

commitResults.messageTitle: Security patch for using remote data as params (#283)
commitResults.messageBody:
Many of our operations use terminal utilities.

This makes our application prone to security issues when we use remote
data as parameters in the terminal.

As a step towards user's safety, let's validate the data to be free of
malicious input before using them in our operations.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#293] List RepoSense team in the README.md (#296)
[#277] Make authors configuration completely optional (#294)
commitResults.messageBody:
Author's information is compulsory in configuration; RepoSense requires
the user to configure an author-config.csv or have the repository owner
put up their own configuration.

This, however, creates a hurdle for the new users to overcome as they
would need to build up the configuration before trying out our tool.

Let's improve the first impression of our tool by making authors
configuration completely optional. All the authors found in history
will be added to the analysis in the event that no author configuration
was found for the repository.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#36] Code view: add controls to expand/collapse all files (#307)
commitResults.messageBody:
Files in code view are shown in open state by default.

With the addition of #282, it can be useful to show only the file
headers as it provides a rough impression of the author's focus area
of contribution and pattern.

Let's add controls to allow user to expand or collapse all the files in
code view at their will.

commitResults.messageTitle: README: update badges (#313)
commitResults.messageBody:
The use of external services, Codacy and Netlify, was not credited on
the landing page of our project.

Let's acknowledge the use of their services by adding their badges in
our README.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#311] code view: differentiate untouched code more (#314)
commitResults.messageBody:
Untouched code uses the same background and font color as written
code.

This allows the possibility of it being passed off as written code
(i.e., give the viewer an impression that the author changed more code
than she actually did) because the only way to differentiate the two
types of code is the color of the line in the gutter.

Let's differentiate the two code types more by adding a light green 
background to written code.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#325] Replace the usage of findstr and grep (#324)
commitResults.messageBody:
We use terminal functions, findstr and grep, to filter the results of
command execution.

This requires us to append os dependent command and also subject to the
limitation of these libraries.

For example, findstr does not support proper regex and has no limiting
quantifier support. This can exposes us to problems when searching for 
patterns that cannot be resolved with the regex of findstr.

Let's replace the use of this 2 functions with our own regex-based text
filtration method, StringsUtil#filterText.

commitResults.messageTitle: README: update url to UserGuide (#327)
commitResults.messageBody:
Documentation link in landing page points to the User Guide in
production.

This can result in users reading the User Guide that is ahead of
release, looking at features irrelevant to the jar they are using.

As users may not how to look for user guide pertaining to their
downloaded version, let's have the url in README to redirect user to
the latest released User Guide.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#328] UserGuide: add instruction for multi-value fields and columns (#333)
commitResults.messageBody:
Some fields in our CLI arguments and configuration files accept
multiple values.

This information was not delivered to the users and users have to infer
this from the given examples.

Let's deliver this concept more explicitly by adding foot notes to
provide the explanation for these fields.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#329] UserGuide: clean up and rearrange sections (#334)
commitResults.messageBody:
The instructions on many sections are incomplete and contains duplicate
information. Also, there is an inconsistency in phrasing of the
titles.

Let's clean up them up and also add a ToC to avoid confusing the users.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#331] UserGuide: update outdated content (#335)
[#342] Fix inconsistent length of contribution bar (#346)
commitResults.messageBody:
Length of the contribution bars varies, dependent on the set of
displayed authors.

This should not be the case. The scale used for the bar should be fixed
for a given period irrespective of which authors are displayed. Search
filters should simply filter out certain authors without changing
anything else.

Let's fixed this by performing the calculations on all authors'
calculation instead of filtered.
Also, since this value should not change in subsequent events, let's
only perform this calculation once and store the value in a global
constant.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#354] granularity#week: fix url not using correct time gap (#355)
commitResults.messageBody:
When the granularity is set to week in report, the url link is still
using a single day time gap.

This should be updated accordingly to show users the commits that were
done in the week.

Let's update the url function to do a conditional check prior to the
generation of hyper link.

commitResults.messageTitle: Fix error occurred from file change due to permission bits modification (#356)
commitResults.messageBody:
We use git diff to extract file infos. In particular rare cases, our
code fails to extracting relevant file infos for certain commits, due
to special extended header lines `old mode 100644` 
`new mode 100755` returned by the git diff, it throws an
AssertionError halfway during the analysis.

This is due to git, besides the file content and changes, it also
tracks the executable bit of the files' permission. As our program did
not foresee this scenario, it crashes upon the occurrence.

Let's fix this by inserting additional guard clause for this scenario
in our FileInfoExtractor.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#363] Make the commits info analysis case insensitive (#364)
commitResults.messageBody:
CommitInfoExtractor uses git log to extract users' commits info.
However, by default, the author matching pattern used in git log is
case sensitive.

This can cause the CommitInfoAnalyzer to miss out some or all their
commits in the analysis. As a result, some authors do not have any
ramps shown in their ramp chart, even though their code view shows line
contributions.

To resolve this problem, let's set the git log regex patterns to be
case insensitive.

commitResults.messageTitle: UserGuide: add commit reminder and instructions (#381)
commitResults.messageBody:
People tend to perform trial and error before committing to the
repository. However, important files, such as json config, will not be
included when we perform the clone on the local repository.

Let's add the instructions to request user to commit the files prior to
analysis.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#395] Fix unhandled IllegalArgumentException in RepoConfiguration#update (#397)
commitResults.messageBody:
Standalone config goes through validation check before being utilized
for analysis. In the event where standalone configs contain invalid
value(s), RepoSense will indicate it by throwing an
IllegalArgumentException.

However, in #395, a standalone config with invalid `ignoreCommitList`
was found in one of the repositories which has caused an intermediate
crash during the analysis. This is due to the IllegalArgumentException
not being properly handled.

Let's handle the IllegalArgumentException by ignoring the standalone
config, also, ensure that none of the fields prior to validation.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#391, #398, #399] Hotfix for outburst of RuntimeException (#400)
commitResults.messageBody:
Due to the nature of our application, and the lack of simpler
alternatives, our application heavily relies on the external command
line utility, `git`. To make use of the tool, we employed a
CommandRunner class which starts a separate process to execute various
operations.

This, however, encourages the outbreak of RuntimeException as numerous
factors can cause `git` to return a non-zero status code and
CommandRunner allows these exceptions to go unchecked.

To prevent RuntimeException from interrupting the analysis of multiple
repos, let's skip the repo under analysis whenever a RunTimeException
occurs.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#310] Apply SRP to various git commands (#408)
commitResults.messageBody:
All the git commands are embedded in the CommandRunner class.

This violates the Single Responsibility Principle as CommandRunner
should only be responsible for the execution, and not the type of
commands.

As a step towards deprecating the use of CommandRunner, let's export
the commands to respective classes and remove the direct dependency on
CommandRunner.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#471] Fix broken link on ramps (#472)
commitResults.messageBody:
The link on ramps are broken; the organization and repository name on
the url links are undefined.

This is due the change in #425 where we encapsulate the names in
another layer of abstraction.

Let's fix the property accessors in v_summary.js to restore the broken
hyperlink.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#375] Config: add new parameter - author's email (#493)
commitResults.messageBody:
When merging a pull request on the GitHub platform, GitHub uses the
author's profile name as the Author Name in the merge commit. Unlike
RepoSense which uses Author Name(s) in tracking the authors'
contribution, GitHub uses emails to track the authors' activity. 

This can however pose a problem to our users. When the authors change
their profile name, they will need to update their list of aliases in
the config files correspondingly in order to maintain the trackability
of RepoSense which can be a hassle to our users.

To provide better experience to our users, let's add the email field to
our csv and json configuration files.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#399] Fix RuntimeException due to ambiguous argument in git rev-list (#505)
commitResults.messageBody:
When a file with the same name as the analyzing branch exist in the
repo, an uncaught RuntimeException will occur due to ambiguous argument
in git rev-list causing RepoSense to crash.

Let's add the `--` revision-path separator in `git rev-list` command to
distinguish the branch name from the ambiguous argument.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#587] Fix unoriented output messages (#593)
commitResults.messageBody:
Some of the messages used in RepoSense are structurally unoriented.

This include the missing transition message where --config flag is
unused, using default path for analysis and the double printing of
the help message, and the confusing arrangement of usage parameters as
shown in #587.

Let's fix these scenarios to improve the quality of our output messages.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#622] CsvParser#parse: fix error handling of `processLine` (#623)
commitResults.messageBody:
When processing a line that is illegal or erroneous, `processLine` will
throw an exception to the caller, `parse`, and the process gets
terminated.

This result in the rise of an issue in
nus-cs3281/2019-dashboard@ef0791f where a misconfigured line in
author-config.csv causes the subsequent lines of authors not being
parsed and added to the analysis.

As the lines in our csv config are meant to be separate entities, let's
ignore any misconfigurations and move on to parsing the subsequent
lines.

commitResults.messageTitle: AboutUs: update team members (#867)
commitResults.messageBody:
As more members join and leave us, it is about time for us to distinct
the active members so that users can easily seek help from us.

Let's move our team list to a new page to separate our active and past
members into different section. Also, let's include and update the
roles to accredit our senior members who have been helping out with
many of the work, including mentoring the newcomers.

commitResults.messageTitle: README: add acknowledgements section (#978)
commitResults.messageBody:
It is required for us to acknowledge the use of free services.

As part of the requirement to apply for the Open Source Plan from
Netlify, let's add a section to feature the usage of their services on
README.
